posts.name: Goktug Yildiz
posts.cooked: I want to learn how to code a swerve drive but the documentation of wpilib isn't very helpful; how can I learn to code a swerve drive without any library?

posts.name: Jeffrey Davis
posts.cooked:
The wpilib library offers tools to simplify hardware communication. To manage your swerve modules effectively:
1. Use an absolute encoder to streamline controlling each module's direction and speed.
2. Leverage built-in classes for translating between module states and overall robot movement, saving development effort.

These approaches simplify complex tasks, avoiding the need for intricate trigonometric calculations. Focus on understanding existing implementations before creating custom solutions. Fine-tuning motor parameters remains essential for optimal performance, allowing for adjustments based on your desired level of complexity.

posts.name: Scott W
posts.cooked:
I wrote this during the Christmas break in 2019, though it is somewhat outdated. In 2020 and 2022, I utilized it to instruct our senior programming students on developing a swerve drive system from scratch.

This document includes a downloadable PDF file titled "4907 ThunderStamps Swerve Drive.pdf" (1.2 MB).

While modern implementations such as YAGSL and CTRE’s swerve generator leverage numerous built-in functions within WPILib, this document predates those advanced tools and demonstrates how to create a swerve drive system entirely from scratch.

Despite lacking access to modern tools, it provides a solid foundation in the underlying mathematics involved.

I wrote this guide a while ago that explains it Swerve Drive How does Swerve Drive work Swerve Drive is a type of autonomous vehicle technology that uses independently driven wheels to move in any direction without turning This allows for precise control and obstacle avoidance Swerve modules are the building blocks of Swerve Drive systems Each module consists of a motorized wheel paired with a sensor array enabling real-time navigation and path planning Swerve modules operate independently allowing them to coordinate movements across a grid layout
